title: 106_hr3636
content: The "Pharmaceutical Freedom Act of 2000" is also known as the "Prescription Drugs Purchased by Individuals Who Have Attained Retirement Age" Act. It introduces an income tax credit for prescription drugs purchased by individuals who have reached Social Security retirement age. The "Pharmaceutical Freedom Act of 2000" introduces an income tax credit for individuals at Social Security retirement age. The credit is 80% of the amount paid for prescribed drugs, with coordination to reduce double benefits with medical expense deductions. The "Pharmaceutical Freedom Act of 2000" introduces an income tax credit for individuals at Social Security retirement age. The credit is 80% of the amount paid for prescribed drugs, with coordination to reduce double benefits with medical expense deductions. No credit allowed for amounts paid from medical savings accounts. Taxpayers can elect not to have the credit apply for a taxable year. Title II of the "Pharmaceutical Freedom Act of 2000" includes amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. Section 201 focuses on facilitating the importation of drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The effective date for the amendments in this section applies to taxable years beginning more than 1 year after the enactment of the Act. Section 801(d) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to allow a person meeting legal requirements to import certain drugs without being the manufacturer, by submitting an application to the Secretary for approval. The drugs eligible for importation are those subject to specific sections or containing insulin. The Secretary must approve the application if it demonstrates the drug meets requirements. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to allow importation of drugs meeting requirements by submitting an application for approval to the Secretary. The Secretary must approve or refuse the application within 60 days, without affecting any patent rights. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs and update references within the Act. SEC. 202. INTERNET SALES OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS. Section 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to allow interstate sale of prescription drugs through an Internet site if certain conditions are met, including compliance with federal and state laws and posting accurate information on the website. The amendment to Section 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act allows for the interstate sale of prescription drugs through an Internet site, provided that the drugs are introduced into interstate commerce. The term 'prescription drug' refers to drugs subject to paragraph (1) of the Act. Before the expiration of the one-year period, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must create regulations for the amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The amendments made by sections 201 and 202 will take effect regardless of the promulgation of these regulations.
